title: Q1: Explain the three main ways to apply CSS styles to a web page
answer: CSS styles can be applied inline using the style attribute, embedded within a style tag in the HTML's head, or linked externally through a CSS file.

title: Q2: How to use variables in Sass?
answer: Variables in Sass are defined using the $ symbol and can be used to store colors, font stacks, or any CSS value to be reused throughout the stylesheet.

title: Q3: What is CSS?
answer: CSS (Cascading Style Sheets) is a stylesheet language used for describing the presentation of a document written in HTML or XML.

title: Q4: What existing CSS frameworks have you used locally, or in production? How would you change/improve them?
answer: Common CSS frameworks include Bootstrap, Tailwind CSS, and Foundation. Improvements could involve simplifying customization, reducing file size, or enhancing documentation.

title: Q5: What is a CSS rule?
answer: A CSS rule consists of a selector and a declaration block, where styles are defined for the elements matched by the selector.

title: Q6: Explain what is a @extend directive used for in Sass?
answer: @extend allows one selector to inherit the styles of another selector, promoting code reuse and reducing duplication.

title: Q7: Have you played around with the new CSS Flexbox or Grid specs?
answer: Flexbox and Grid are modern CSS layout models for building responsive designs, Flexbox being more suited for one-dimensional layouts and Grid for two-dimensional layouts.

title: Q8: What is Sass?
answer: Sass (Syntactically Awesome Style Sheets) is a CSS preprocessor that adds features like variables, nested rules, and mixins to CSS.

title: Q9: List out the key features for Sass
answer: Key features of Sass include variables, nested rules, mixins, inheritance, and partials with @import.

title: Q10: What is the difference between classes and IDs in CSS?
answer: Classes are reusable selectors for styling while IDs are unique to a page element and are used for specific styling.

title: Q11: Describe floats and how they work
answer: Float is a CSS positioning property that shifts an element to the left or right, allowing content to wrap around it.

title: Q12: What Selector Nesting in Sass is used for?
answer: Selector nesting in Sass allows you to write nested selectors in a way that follows the HTML's hierarchy, enhancing readability and maintainability.

title: Q13: What is DOM (Document Object Model) and how is it linked to CSS?
answer: The DOM is a programming interface for web documents, which represents the structure of a document. CSS uses selectors to style elements within this structure.

title: Q14: Explain the CSS box model and the layout components that it consists of
answer: The CSS box model is a layout model that consists of margins, borders, padding, and the content itself.

title: Q15: Explain CSS sprites, and how you would implement them on a page or site.
answer: CSS sprites are a technique to reduce HTTP requests by combining multiple images into one and using CSS to display specific parts of the image.

title: Q16: List out the data types that Sass supports.
answer: Sass supports numbers, strings, colors, booleans, nulls, lists, and maps.

title: Q17: How is responsive design different from adaptive design?
answer: Responsive design uses fluid grids to adapt to different screen sizes, while adaptive design uses fixed layouts, adjusting only at specific breakpoints.

title: Q18: What is CSS selectors? Name some.
answer: CSS selectors are patterns used to select the elements you want to style. Common selectors include class, ID, element, attribute, and pseudo-class selectors.

title: Q19: What does Accessibility (a11y) mean?
answer: Accessibility (a11y) refers to designing websites so they are usable by people with various disabilities, including visual, auditory, physical, and cognitive impairments.

title: Q20: Describe pseudo-elements and discuss what they are used for.
answer: Pseudo-elements are used to style specific parts of an element, such as ::before and ::after for inserting content before or after an element's content.

title: Q21: How does CSS actually work (under the hood of browser)?
answer: CSS is parsed by the browser to build a style sheet and match it with the DOM to produce the render tree, which is then used to paint the content on the screen.

title: Q22: Explain your understanding of the box model and how you would tell the browser in CSS to render your layout in different box models.
answer: The box model consists of margins, borders, padding, and content. The box-sizing property in CSS can toggle between content-box and border-box models.

title: Q23: What is a Grid System in CSS?
answer: A grid system in CSS is a layout structure for arranging content in a structured grid fashion, commonly used for responsive design.

title: Q24: How would you approach fixing browser-specific styling issues?
answer: Use CSS resets, fallbacks, vendor prefixes, and conditional comments to fix browser-specific styling issues.

title: Q25: What are the advantages/disadvantages of using CSS preprocessors?
answer: Advantages include variables, nesting, and mixins, which enhance code reusability and maintainability. Disadvantages involve added compilation steps and potential complexity.

title: Q26: What's the difference between SCSS and Sass?
answer: Sass offers two syntaxes: SCSS (Sassy CSS) and the indented syntax. SCSS uses braces and semicolons, fitting more with standard CSS, while the indented syntax is more concise.

title: Q27: Explain the usage of table-layout property.
answer: The table-layout property governs the layout algorithm of a table. 'auto' adjusts the column width based on content, while 'fixed' maintains a consistent column width.

title: Q28: Have you ever worked with retina graphics? If so, when and what techniques did you use?
answer: Retina graphics cater to high-resolution displays using techniques like SVGs, responsive images, and CSS media queries for varying resolutions.

title: Q29: What's the difference between a relative, fixed, absolute and static ally positioned element?
answer: Static is default with no positioning, relative is relative to its normal position, absolute is positioned relative to nearest positioned ancestor, and fixed is always relative to the viewport.

title: Q30: Whatâ€™s the difference between resetting and normalizing CSS? Which would you choose, and why?
answer: Resetting removes all default browser styles, while normalizing preserves useful styles in a consistent way. Choice depends on desired consistency vs. needing a clean slate.

title: Q31: What is CSS preprocessor and why to use one?
answer: A CSS preprocessor extends CSS with mechanisms like variables, functions, and nesting to write more maintainable and efficient code.

title: Q32: Is there any reason you'd want to use translate() instead of absolute positioning, or vice-versa? And why?
answer: translate() can be more efficient for animations as it is GPU-accelerated, while absolute positioning is more suitable for specific layout requirements.

title: Q33: What does * { box-sizing: border-box; } do? What are its advantages?
answer: It sets all elements to calculate width and height including padding and border, simplifying layout calculations.

title: Q34: Describe z-index and how a stacking context is formed.
answer: z-index controls the stacking order of elements along the z-axis. A stacking context is formed by elements with a position value other than static and certain CSS properties.

title: Q35: Explain the purpose of clearing floats in CSS.
answer: Clearing floats ensures that container elements correctly enclose floated items by preventing elements from collapsing in height.

title: Q36: Explain the basic rules of CSS Specificity.
answer: CSS specificity determines which rule overrides another based on hierarchy: inline styles, IDs, classes, attributes, and elements from highest to lowest priority.

title: Q37: Have you ever used a grid system, and if so, what do you prefer?
answer: Grid systems like Bootstrap or CSS Grid assist in creating responsive layouts. Preference depends on project needs, complexity, and flexibility.

title: Q38: How do you optimize your webpages for print?
answer: Use a separate print stylesheet to adjust layout, hide unnecessary elements, and ensure readability with specific print styles.

title: Q39: Can you explain the difference between coding a website to be responsive versus using a mobile-first strategy?
answer: Responsive design ensures the layout adapts to any screen size, while mobile-first prioritizes mobile view in design and styling.

title: Q40: What are the different ways to visually hide content (and make it available only for screen readers)?
answer: Use CSS properties like clip-path, opacity: 0, or positioning off-screen while keeping accessibility concerns addressed with proper ARIA attributes.
